Technology in focus this week in business, Giants including Apple, Facebook and Google parent Alphabet all set to report their quarterly results. We've got the preview for you on tech.

New Science, the housing market is coming back. A new survey says homes are flying off the market so buyers better act fast.

Meanwhile, markets this morning -- really flat in on the session. As you can see, things have turned negative, but just by a fraction. So Dow Industrials now indicated lower by about two points.

Later this week, investors will have a lot to digest between a host of economic data like the GDP report is out at the end of the week, and a number of high profile earnings news coming out.

In Europe, this morning stocks are higher across the board, take a look. Well, not across the board. The FT 100 is actually down at 10 points, but things have improved in the Eurozone, Cac Quarante in Paris up half a percent, Dax index in Germany up almost 1 percent.

In Asia, overnight mixed performances, as you can see here, also just fractional moves as well.

The city of Philadelphia prepping for expected protests today, as the Democratic National Convention kicks off. Key speakers tonight include first lady, Michelle Obama, and Senator Bernie Sanders.

Fox News's Doug McKelway is live in Philly with a preview. Doug, good morning to you.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS: Morning Maria, and there's been a bit of breaking news from the Democratic National Convention this morning. They have announced that the keynote speaker for tonight will be Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren. This is probably a very, very sound decision by the DNC.

As you know, Elizabeth Warren has been an attacked dog nipping at heels of Donald Trump. Throughout this campaign she goes head-to-head with him in Twitter wars, and matches insult for insult. And so, in that sense, it will probably a very -- be a very effective strategy in trying to divert attention from the story DuJour of the Democratic National Convention. The story of the convention, thus far, which is the e-mail scandal and the resignation of Chairman Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

She has come to a bit of a soft landing in the sense. She has been picked up by the Clinton campaign to serve as an honorary co-chairman. But the damage has been done, and her resignation is something that had to be done, because -- simply to see her coming out on this stage, you know, walk out on a daze (ph) in front of all these delegates to face a chorus of boos in a way that Ted Cruz faced, of course, the boos when is he failed to introduce Donald Trump and to support Donald Trump at the Republican convention. Something they did not want to see repeated here.

Clinton has been successful in alienating herself from the scandal as well as she told "60 Minutes."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE: I don't know anything about these e- mails, I haven't followed it. But I am very proud of the campaign that I ran. I can't speak to people who were not working for me, who were saying whatever they were saying, I can't speak to that. I can only speak to my campaign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: For his part, Bernie Sanders has remained remarkably calm throughout this scandal. His convention speech also scheduled to be delivered tonight. Will be chock-full of insults directed at Donald Trump, compliments directed towards Hillary Clinton but he won't be firing away from within the Democratic tent, perhaps because he is long suspected a conspiracy to deprive him of the nomination.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNIE SANDERS: I think it's outrageous, but it is not a great shock to me. It's what we talked about six months ago. I mean, there's no question to my mind and I think no question to any objective observer's mind that the DNC was supporting Hillary Clinton, was in opposition to our campaign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: Those allegiances of Bernie Sanders supporters are not being as gentle as that thousands gathered on the streets of downtown Philadelphia yesterday to protest. It was a larger gathering than anything we saw.

In Cleveland, albeit, it was a peaceful demonstration. They'll be moving up to this neck of the woods today about 20 miles north of where they protested yesterday to FDR Park.

The impressive thing about their appearance there yesterday was, they came out in intense heat and humidity, did not dissuade them did at all. Today, a different situation, we had downpours here in Philadelphia. We'll see if they've been able -- if they will be able to withstand that. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Doug thanks so much. Doug McKelway there -- here in Philly with us. How will the DNC e-mail leak impact day one and the views of delegates and voters.

I want to bring in former advisor to President Bill Clinton and co-author of the new book, "Armageddon, How Trump Can Beat Hillary" and that is, of course, Dick Morris. Dick, good to see you.

DICK MORRIS, ARMAGEDDON AUTHOR: Good to be here with you.

BARTIROMO: So what do you think? What's the impact of all this?

MORRIS: Well, I think that it's notable that Trump went out of his way to appease the conservatives in his party who he largely defeated by naming Pence. And Hillary went out of her way to name Kaine, who is clearly not a liberal and does nothing to placate Sanders and Warren.

So when Sanders and Warren addressed the convention tonight, the big thing we'll notice is that they would not chosen to be vice president. And in a sense -- no matter how attractive they are, people are saying that shows that their views and Hillary's are fundamentally different. So I think it really casts a shadow over the whole thing. But, you know Maria, it can get worse. When .

BARTIROMO: What do you mean it can -- how is it going to get worse?

MORRIS: Well, when a bomb hits you, you wonder if the plane is still overhead. And on June 14th, there was a leak from anonymous sources in Russia, probably the Kremlin, that they possessed a number of Hillary's state department e-mails. And that they may release them at a time that might be inconvenient to Hillary, and that's something to keep your eye on all convention. Because that would establish that the e-mail server was hacked and was hacked by our enemies.

BARTIROMO: Yeah. That's really interesting, Dagen, because this whole time she is saying we weren't hacked, everything is fine.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Which in the interview with "60 Minutes" she went out of her way to make that point and put an exclamation on the discussion about that very e-mail server.

I want to ask Dick this in terms of a Tim Kaine picked The Wall Street Journal editorial page, essentially says that Tim Kaine is a pick for when she wins, so -- and when she begins to govern, that she seems to be so confident in getting the far left vote, and in getting the votes that -- of Sanders or Warren would appeal to, that she's basically skipping November and going right to governing starting in January with Tim Kaine.

MORRIS: Well, I can't think that she is that na[ve. I think there's a different explanation for Tim Kaine. You're right. It's confounding as a political proposition. But I think that the key is Tim Kaine's letter that he sent to the banks three days before he was nominated, avowing that he would opposed stricter regulation of the big banks.

Now, normally when you're on a short list for V.P. you keep your mouth shut. But he overtly sent that letter, and I think it was to get the banks to lobby Hillary to put him on the ticket. And I think that what you are seeing here is Hillary reassuring her financial controllers that she's still on the reservation by picking Kaine.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PACK NATIONAL CO-CHAIR: Dick, good morning. This is Morgan. I'm wondering, what can Bernie Sanders say tonight? And the comparison that I'm thinking it was four years ago, Bill Clinton sort of saved Barack Obama in his reelection by giving that powerful speech at the convention. Do you expect Bernie Sanders to pull a Bill Clinton four years ago or a Ted Cruz last week when it comes to Hillary Clinton tonight?

MORRIS: Well, I think it will be a Bernie. And I think he will use the opportunity to articulate again his points of view. I think he'll attract Trump aggressively. I think he'll mildly praise Hillary. But I think that the real point here is that his voters are the swing the vote in this election.

Try to make that point in -- on again, in my book. The Republicans can run not just with the right jab, doing the conservative issues but they need to throw a left hook coming around Hillary and talking to the Sanders voters in the rear. And I think Trump did a very good job of that in his speech. And I think this e-mail scandal and the choice of Kaine both of which essentially to have lifted the Democratic Party to stop it, really undermine Hillary.

BARTIROMO: He's been trying to do that. You know, Trump trying to reach out to those Bernie Sanders voters and Hillary is being forced to defend the multiple scandals surrounding her and her entire political record. She gave that first interview with the V.P. choice Senator Kaine, and Clinton claimed that she is judged on a different standard than others are judged. Listen to this Dick Morris.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: I think that it is fair to say there has been a concerted effort to convince people like that young man of something. Nobody is quite sure what but of something. I often feel like there's the Hillary standard and then there's the standard for everybody else.

SCOTT PELLEY, "60 MINUTES" HOST: What's the Hillary standard?

CLINTON: Well, it is, you know, a lot of as you saw at the Republican Convention, unfounded, inaccurate, main spirited attacks with no basis in truth reality which take on a life of their own.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MORRIS: Well .

BARTIROMO: So, what do you think? Is there a Hillary standard?

MORRIS: I'm glad his speech writer didn't call it a vast right-wing conspiracy. May be they used that one already. But I think that -- yeah, when somebody comes out of a bar at night, they had a nice drink. When the guy has five DUI (ph), there's a question to whether they shouldn't have been in that bar in the first place, and that is the Hillary standard.

But I think that it is -- when we look at this convention, Donald Trump used this convention to show who Donald Trump is. He was front and center of his family, his wife, his kids. Hillary is going to use this convention to hide herself. She is not running. The first woman is running. She's not running, pro-choice is running and pro-gun control. She's the only person between Donald Trump and the presidency.

And in .

BARTIROMO: That is great analysis, yeah.

MORRIS: . in fact she advances through generic rather than through the specific of her.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, that's a great point. You know, and maybe (ph) she might also have created that standard for herself by just doing things like, oh, I am going to -- you have my own e-mail server, because that's what I'm going to do and nobody else can do that.

TONY SAYEGH, JAMESTOWN ASSOCIATES: The most of these in part of that interview was she said that all these concerns about her honesty untrustworthiness were baseless. Meanwhile, we know from the Clinton Foundation contribution for foreign government, the server and et cetera, but Delegates County saying, you've known Hillary Clinton for decades. You advise the Clintons a long time ago. Has Hillary changed or is this the same Hillary you sat down with face to face when you first met the Clinton's back. I believe it was in the 80's.

BARTIMORO: Real quick, Dick.

MORRIS: I think best say to say it, she's metastasized. In the beginning, there was the incipient dishonesty, there was the incipient paranoia and secrecy.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MORRIS: There was the incipient dishonesty corruption but it's grown. It's metastasized. It's taken her over. You know a person from 70 years old, you knew when they were 30, and you could see them going off the track but not that much.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MORRIS: But then a 60s and 70s you say, oh, my god, look at what they've become, that's Hillary.

BARTIROMO: Well, you know them really well. And Dick, good to see you, sir. Thank you so much.

MORRIS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, quite morning in terms of futures. Take a look, we're really not far from where the market finished the day yesterday, and yet earnings really driving the story. Handful of names on the new this morning.

SolarCity is (inaudible) higher. The company reportedly closed to emerge their deal with Tesla. Reuters is reporting that the two companies are in final stages of talks in carrying out due diligence on a potential deal. Stock as you can see looking higher.

Well, the initial report of the deal came out last month. Questions were raised because Elon Musk is the CEO of Tesla and the Chairman of SolarCity. Musk has refused himself from voting on this deal.

We'll continue to track the latest development following a fatal explosion in Germany yesterday. Cheryl Casone with that right now and the other head lines from our New York headquarters. Cheryl, over to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yeah, that's right Maria. The various interior minister says he believes the incident was likely an Islamist suicide attack. Police say a 27-year old Syrian man blew himself up after he was turned away from an open air music festival in Ansbach.

Police believe the man who killed himself was motivated after being denied asylum in Germany. He was already known to them for a recent drug misdemeanor. At least 12 others were injured in the suicide attack.

We'll here at home. A wildfire in Southern California, destroying 18 homes and rapidly gaining straight two days after it broke out. The fire being described as a freight train by some setting so much smoke into the air that planes making water drops on it, had to be grounded (ph) at one point. Thousands of people forced to evacuate.

This fire Maria has burned at least 34 square miles but fire officials say that size may now have doubled. Of course, it's dark in California. We'll see what happens when the sun comes up this morning.

And finally, the housing market, showing signs of improvement. (Inaudible) said that homes are selling an average of a week faster than they did just one year ago. This is the supply of nearly 5 percent lower than last year. Homes are being sold after about 78 days on the market. The average U.S. home is currently worth $187,000, Maria, that's a 5.4 percent increase from June of last year. That's for prices from 2015.

But Maria, remember, that we're also looking about 3.5 percent for the 30- year fixed year mortgage right now, that's also affecting sales. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Spotlight on technology this week, setting the stage on market. Coming up, we're going to preview the week. We'll tell you what to expect, out of a whole host (ph) of earnings within the tech sector.

Plus, we're coming to you live from Democratic National Convention here in Philadelphia. We'll tell about what to expect as the DNC kicks off today. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Let's check market this morning with a lot of earnings coming out this weekend some economic data that will certainly set the tone and the Fed. Two-day meeting, the Federal Reserve is having this week.

Ahead of all of that, the market is looking fractionally higher. It keeps going back and forth though between positive and negative territory, this following another record closing high for the S&P 500 on Friday.

Investors are gearing up for a slow of Vect (ph) technology earning including S&P components, Apple which is also a Dow component, reporting earnings tomorrow. Facebook is out on Wednesday. Amazon is out and Google parent Alphabet are out with their results on Thursday.

This is going to be a big week. You also have a two-day Federal Reserve meeting which ends on Wednesday. We're not going to see rates move higher but we're going to be focused on the language out of the Fed, and what they say or suggest about the next meeting.

Recon Capital Chief Investment Officer, Kevin Kelley with us standing by in our New York studios. Technology earnings should set the tone, what do you expect on earnings? Is the Fed a factor? What drives market this week, Kevin?

KEVIN KELLEY, RECON CAPITAL CIO: It's going to be a very, very wild week especially for the Nasdaq 100. You're going to have about 40 percent of the companies reporting this week alone. So that's going to dictate a lot of the market action.

And as you alluded to earlier, the big tech names are really going to drive that but also biotech will be reporting this week as well. And you're seeing a lot of these names, are big growers in their space, except for Apple. Apple is expected to have 22 to 25 percent revenue decline and that's because of the refreshed cycle on the iPhone.

So, we're going to have to see where software and services going that route but you're seeing all the other names including Facebook, Amazon. You're seeing their growth be pretty significant, above 20 percent on the top line revenue growth and 15 percent on the earnings growth.

So people are really going to be focused on that, because companies are going to give their guidance, but it's expected to do very well. And these are companies that are giving a good value. So when you look at the tech sector alone, it's training in a 20 perfect discount to its forward earnings on a historical basis. So, people maybe getting into this and really actually help make this sector move higher and move the overall market higher this week.

BARTIROMO: Even Amazon? That's the company that's -- not going to cover up the flow (ph), right Dagen? That stock is up.

MCDOWELL: Price is up -- maybe price for perfection and the question is, in terms of the forward-looking earnings are those estimates wrong? Do they need to come down because that made -- that could make the stocks not look like .

BARTIROMO: I'm not beating (ph) against Amazon.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, Apple is down 6 percent this year. It really fell off a cliff. It's come back a little bit but in terms of potential upside there, I've heard people talking about that.

KELLEY: Yeah .

BARTIROMO: With Amazon -- yeah.

KELLEY: It's really limited upside on Apple but -- just so you know on the Amazon front, Amazon is a great company that hasn't really focused on earnings. They've really focused on revenue growth. So when people start talking about a fundamental basis and their earnings, you can't focus on that, because what they could do is they could actually slash all of their expenditures and really make it into a great value stock if they wanted to but they're not focused on that. That's why you're seeing in perform quarter over quarter on a basis. That's why you're seeing lead even in the Cloud space.

So, their Amazon is going to be a company that ends up being a Cloud company that happens to have an eCommerce platform.

BARTIROMO: Yeah. You know what? Investors have not been bothered by that that they focus on revenue growth. They keep buying the stock.

MCDOWELL: They can hold their nose only so long and then they have to breath through their nose and look out block (ph).

BARTIROMO: We'll see. Kevin, any other highlights from your standpoint? Do you care about the Fed, Tuesday, Wednesday?

KELLEY: I don't think the Fed is really muted right now especially because people are not expecting a move, and if they are expecting a move they're looking it to be in December or early next year. So people -- investors aren't really focused on that, and they're not even focused on the bank of Japan either because of the move last month.

So, people were going to be focused on the market. Yup, exactly. All about earnings.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, I think (ph) the Japan, is on Friday. All right, Kevin, thank you.

We are awaiting big news this morning form month all about earnings from Verizon reports out that say it is going to be completing inking a $5 billion deal to acquire Yahoo. What it means for CEO Marissa Mayer and shareholders of Yahoo and Verizon. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Live from the 2016 Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. You are watching a special edition of Mornings with Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good Monday morning everybody, welcome back. I am Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, July 25th.

urn:contentItem:5KB2-S631-JBHT-D0Y4-00000-00Democratic Convention Opens; Disarray at the DNC; Clinton Campaign Manager Robby Mook Blames Russia for Leaked E-mail; Verizon Acquiring Yahoo2016-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:31ZLexisNexisDemocratic Convention Opens; Disarray at the DNC; Clinton Campaign Manager Robby Mook Blames Russia for Leaked E-mail; Verizon Acquiring YahooLanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Monday morning everybody, welcome back, I'm Maria Bartiromo coming to you live from the Democratic National Convention here in Philadelphia this morning.

It is Monday, July 25th, here are your top stories, 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast right now.

Drama at the Democratic National Convention, and it has not even started yet, it starts today at 4:00 p.m. Eastern.

Party Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz announcing she will resign after an e-mail leaked shows that the DNC favored Hillary Clinton over rival Bernie Sanders throughout the primary season.

Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook blaming Russia for the attack.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBBY MOOK, CAMPAIGN MANAGER, HILLARY CLINTON 2016 CAMPAIGN: Well, I think the DNC needs to look into this and take appropriate action, and I'm sure that they will.

What's disturbing to us is that we -- experts are telling us that Russian state hackers broke into the DNC, stole these e-mails, and other experts are now saying that the Russians are releasing these e-mails for the purpose of actually helping Donald Trump.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, earlier in this program, former presidential candidate Dennis Kucinich said Sanders should have his own Ted Cruz moment at the convention tonight.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: You think Bernie Sanders should do more here?

DENNIS KUCINICH, FORMER CONGRESSMAN: Well, I actually think that it's time for him to consider withdrawing the endorsement because it's not just about him, it's about a movement that he represents which got 46 percent of the votes.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And the movement is reacting, the controversy has Sanders supporters up in arms this morning.

Protesters have already hit the streets this morning, they were there all day yesterday that you can see there right there.

Breaking news overnight meanwhile. Another shooting at a nightclub in Florida. At least two people have been killed, seventeen others injured.

Authorities are searching for suspects, we have the latest details coming up. A dangerous heat wave ripping half of the country.

A look at when temperatures will begin to drop coming up. And then the deal of the day, Verizon acquiring Yahoo for a value of $4.8 billion.

Yahoo shares down in the pre-market, what it means for CEO Marissa Mayer's future coming up.

Markets moving fractionally this morning, edging higher, take a look at what we're looking at, at the open.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average expected to open up just about 9 points this morning, fractional moves.

Later in the week, a whole host of things that the market will get impacted from. Investors will have a lot to digest this week between economic data, a two-day Fed meeting, a Bank of Japan meeting and a lot of earnings particularly coming out of the tech sector.

In Europe this morning, stocks are higher, take a look, we are looking at gains pretty much across the board. The Dax index in Germany up about 1 percent, leading index there.

And in Asia overnight, mixed performances as you will see fractional moves, not too far from where they began the session.

All those stories coming up this morning, and joining me to talk about it is Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Maverick PAC National Co-Chair Morgan Ortagus and Republican strategist Tony Sayegh.

New Science, the housing market is coming back. A new survey says homes are flying off the market so buyers better act fast.

Meanwhile, markets this morning -- really flat in on the session. As you can see, things have turned negative, but just by a fraction. So Dow Industrials now indicated lower by about two points.

Later this week, investors will have a lot to digest between a host of economic data like the GDP report is out at the end of the week, and a number of high profile earnings news coming out.

In Europe, this morning stocks are higher across the board, take a look. Well, not across the board. The FT 100 is actually down at 10 points, but things have improved in the Eurozone, Cac Quarante in Paris up half a percent, Dax index in Germany up almost 1 percent.

In Asia, overnight mixed performances, as you can see here, also just fractional moves as well.

The city of Philadelphia prepping for expected protests today, as the Democratic National Convention kicks off. Key speakers tonight include first lady, Michelle Obama, and Senator Bernie Sanders.

Fox News's Doug McKelway is live in Philly with a preview. Doug, good morning to you.

DOUG MCKELWAY, FOX NEWS: Morning Maria, and there's been a bit of breaking news from the Democratic National Convention this morning. They have announced that the keynote speaker for tonight will be Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren. This is probably a very, very sound decision by the DNC.

As you know, Elizabeth Warren has been an attacked dog nipping at heels of Donald Trump. Throughout this campaign she goes head-to-head with him in Twitter wars, and matches insult for insult. And so, in that sense, it will probably a very -- be a very effective strategy in trying to divert attention from the story DuJour of the Democratic National Convention. The story of the convention, thus far, which is the e-mail scandal and the resignation of Chairman Debbie Wasserman Schultz.

She has come to a bit of a soft landing in the sense. She has been picked up by the Clinton campaign to serve as an honorary co-chairman. But the damage has been done, and her resignation is something that had to be done, because -- simply to see her coming out on this stage, you know, walk out on a daze (ph) in front of all these delegates to face a chorus of boos in a way that Ted Cruz faced, of course, the boos when is he failed to introduce Donald Trump and to support Donald Trump at the Republican convention. Something they did not want to see repeated here.

Clinton has been successful in alienating herself from the scandal as well as she told "60 Minutes."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, DEMOCRATIC NOMINEE: I don't know anything about these e- mails, I haven't followed it. But I am very proud of the campaign that I ran. I can't speak to people who were not working for me, who were saying whatever they were saying, I can't speak to that. I can only speak to my campaign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: For his part, Bernie Sanders has remained remarkably calm throughout this scandal. His convention speech also scheduled to be delivered tonight. Will be chock-full of insults directed at Donald Trump, compliments directed towards Hillary Clinton but he won't be firing away from within the Democratic tent, perhaps because he is long suspected a conspiracy to deprive him of the nomination.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BERNIE SANDERS: I think it's outrageous, but it is not a great shock to me. It's what we talked about six months ago. I mean, there's no question to my mind and I think no question to any objective observer's mind that the DNC was supporting Hillary Clinton, was in opposition to our campaign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCKELWAY: Those allegiances of Bernie Sanders supporters are not being as gentle as that thousands gathered on the streets of downtown Philadelphia yesterday to protest. It was a larger gathering than anything we saw.

In Cleveland, albeit, it was a peaceful demonstration. They'll be moving up to this neck of the woods today about 20 miles north of where they protested yesterday to FDR Park.

The impressive thing about their appearance there yesterday was, they came out in intense heat and humidity, did not dissuade them did at all. Today, a different situation, we had downpours here in Philadelphia. We'll see if they've been able -- if they will be able to withstand that. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Doug thanks so much. Doug McKelway there -- here in Philly with us. How will the DNC e-mail leak impact day one and the views of delegates and voters.

I want to bring in former advisor to President Bill Clinton and co-author of the new book, "Armageddon, How Trump Can Beat Hillary" and that is, of course, Dick Morris. Dick, good to see you.

DICK MORRIS, ARMAGEDDON AUTHOR: Good to be here with you.

BARTIROMO: So what do you think? What's the impact of all this?

MORRIS: Well, I think that it's notable that Trump went out of his way to appease the conservatives in his party who he largely defeated by naming Pence. And Hillary went out of her way to name Kaine, who is clearly not a liberal and does nothing to placate Sanders and Warren.

So when Sanders and Warren addressed the convention tonight, the big thing we'll notice is that they would not chosen to be vice president. And in a sense -- no matter how attractive they are, people are saying that shows that their views and Hillary's are fundamentally different. So I think it really casts a shadow over the whole thing. But, you know Maria, it can get worse. When .

BARTIROMO: What do you mean it can -- how is it going to get worse?

MORRIS: Well, when a bomb hits you, you wonder if the plane is still overhead. And on June 14th, there was a leak from anonymous sources in Russia, probably the Kremlin, that they possessed a number of Hillary's state department e-mails. And that they may release them at a time that might be inconvenient to Hillary, and that's something to keep your eye on all convention. Because that would establish that the e-mail server was hacked and was hacked by our enemies.

BARTIROMO: Yeah. That's really interesting, Dagen, because this whole time she is saying we weren't hacked, everything is fine.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Which in the interview with "60 Minutes" she went out of her way to make that point and put an exclamation on the discussion about that very e-mail server.

I want to ask Dick this in terms of a Tim Kaine picked The Wall Street Journal editorial page, essentially says that Tim Kaine is a pick for when she wins, so -- and when she begins to govern, that she seems to be so confident in getting the far left vote, and in getting the votes that -- of Sanders or Warren would appeal to, that she's basically skipping November and going right to governing starting in January with Tim Kaine.

MORRIS: Well, I can't think that she is that na[ve. I think there's a different explanation for Tim Kaine. You're right. It's confounding as a political proposition. But I think that the key is Tim Kaine's letter that he sent to the banks three days before he was nominated, avowing that he would opposed stricter regulation of the big banks.

Now, normally when you're on a short list for V.P. you keep your mouth shut. But he overtly sent that letter, and I think it was to get the banks to lobby Hillary to put him on the ticket. And I think that what you are seeing here is Hillary reassuring her financial controllers that she's still on the reservation by picking Kaine.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PACK NATIONAL CO-CHAIR: Dick, good morning. This is Morgan. I'm wondering, what can Bernie Sanders say tonight? And the comparison that I'm thinking it was four years ago, Bill Clinton sort of saved Barack Obama in his reelection by giving that powerful speech at the convention. Do you expect Bernie Sanders to pull a Bill Clinton four years ago or a Ted Cruz last week when it comes to Hillary Clinton tonight?

MORRIS: Well, I think it will be a Bernie. And I think he will use the opportunity to articulate again his points of view. I think he'll attract Trump aggressively. I think he'll mildly praise Hillary. But I think that the real point here is that his voters are the swing the vote in this election.

Try to make that point in -- on again, in my book. The Republicans can run not just with the right jab, doing the conservative issues but they need to throw a left hook coming around Hillary and talking to the Sanders voters in the rear. And I think Trump did a very good job of that in his speech. And I think this e-mail scandal and the choice of Kaine both of which essentially to have lifted the Democratic Party to stop it, really undermine Hillary.

BARTIROMO: He's been trying to do that. You know, Trump trying to reach out to those Bernie Sanders voters and Hillary is being forced to defend the multiple scandals surrounding her and her entire political record. She gave that first interview with the V.P. choice Senator Kaine, and Clinton claimed that she is judged on a different standard than others are judged. Listen to this Dick Morris.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: I think that it is fair to say there has been a concerted effort to convince people like that young man of something. Nobody is quite sure what but of something. I often feel like there's the Hillary standard and then there's the standard for everybody else.

SCOTT PELLEY, "60 MINUTES" HOST: What's the Hillary standard?

CLINTON: Well, it is, you know, a lot of as you saw at the Republican Convention, unfounded, inaccurate, main spirited attacks with no basis in truth reality which take on a life of their own.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MORRIS: Well .

BARTIROMO: So, what do you think? Is there a Hillary standard?

MORRIS: I'm glad his speech writer didn't call it a vast right-wing conspiracy. May be they used that one already. But I think that -- yeah, when somebody comes out of a bar at night, they had a nice drink. When the guy has five DUI (ph), there's a question to whether they shouldn't have been in that bar in the first place, and that is the Hillary standard.

But I think that it is -- when we look at this convention, Donald Trump used this convention to show who Donald Trump is. He was front and center of his family, his wife, his kids. Hillary is going to use this convention to hide herself. She is not running. The first woman is running. She's not running, pro-choice is running and pro-gun control. She's the only person between Donald Trump and the presidency.

And in .

BARTIROMO: That is great analysis, yeah.

MORRIS: . in fact she advances through generic rather than through the specific of her.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, that's a great point. You know, and maybe (ph) she might also have created that standard for herself by just doing things like, oh, I am going to -- you have my own e-mail server, because that's what I'm going to do and nobody else can do that.

TONY SAYEGH, JAMESTOWN ASSOCIATES: The most of these in part of that interview was she said that all these concerns about her honesty untrustworthiness were baseless. Meanwhile, we know from the Clinton Foundation contribution for foreign government, the server and et cetera, but Delegates County saying, you've known Hillary Clinton for decades. You advise the Clintons a long time ago. Has Hillary changed or is this the same Hillary you sat down with face to face when you first met the Clinton's back. I believe it was in the 80's.

BARTIMORO: Real quick, Dick.

MORRIS: I think best say to say it, she's metastasized. In the beginning, there was the incipient dishonesty, there was the incipient paranoia and secrecy.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MORRIS: There was the incipient dishonesty corruption but it's grown. It's metastasized. It's taken her over. You know a person from 70 years old, you knew when they were 30, and you could see them going off the track but not that much.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MORRIS: But then a 60s and 70s you say, oh, my god, look at what they've become, that's Hillary.

BARTIROMO: Well, you know them really well. And Dick, good to see you, sir. Thank you so much.

MORRIS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, quite morning in terms of futures. Take a look, we're really not far from where the market finished the day yesterday, and yet earnings really driving the story. Handful of names on the new this morning.

SolarCity is (inaudible) higher. The company reportedly closed to emerge their deal with Tesla. Reuters is reporting that the two companies are in final stages of talks in carrying out due diligence on a potential deal. Stock as you can see looking higher.

Well, the initial report of the deal came out last month. Questions were raised because Elon Musk is the CEO of Tesla and the Chairman of SolarCity. Musk has refused himself from voting on this deal.

We'll continue to track the latest development following a fatal explosion in Germany yesterday. Cheryl Casone with that right now and the other head lines from our New York headquarters. Cheryl, over to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yeah, that's right Maria. The various interior minister says he believes the incident was likely an Islamist suicide attack. Police say a 27-year old Syrian man blew himself up after he was turned away from an open air music festival in Ansbach.

Police believe the man who killed himself was motivated after being denied asylum in Germany. He was already known to them for a recent drug misdemeanor. At least 12 others were injured in the suicide attack.

We'll here at home. A wildfire in Southern California, destroying 18 homes and rapidly gaining straight two days after it broke out. The fire being described as a freight train by some setting so much smoke into the air that planes making water drops on it, had to be grounded (ph) at one point. Thousands of people forced to evacuate.

This fire Maria has burned at least 34 square miles but fire officials say that size may now have doubled. Of course, it's dark in California. We'll see what happens when the sun comes up this morning.

And finally, the housing market, showing signs of improvement. (Inaudible) said that homes are selling an average of a week faster than they did just one year ago. This is the supply of nearly 5 percent lower than last year. Homes are being sold after about 78 days on the market. The average U.S. home is currently worth $187,000, Maria, that's a 5.4 percent increase from June of last year. That's for prices from 2015.

But Maria, remember, that we're also looking about 3.5 percent for the 30- year fixed year mortgage right now, that's also affecting sales. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Spotlight on technology this week, setting the stage on market. Coming up, we're going to preview the week. We'll tell you what to expect, out of a whole host (ph) of earnings within the tech sector.

Plus, we're coming to you live from Democratic National Convention here in Philadelphia. We'll tell about what to expect as the DNC kicks off today. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Let's check market this morning with a lot of earnings coming out this weekend some economic data that will certainly set the tone and the Fed. Two-day meeting, the Federal Reserve is having this week.

Ahead of all of that, the market is looking fractionally higher. It keeps going back and forth though between positive and negative territory, this following another record closing high for the S&P 500 on Friday.

Investors are gearing up for a slow of Vect (ph) technology earning including S&P components, Apple which is also a Dow component, reporting earnings tomorrow. Facebook is out on Wednesday. Amazon is out and Google parent Alphabet are out with their results on Thursday.

This is going to be a big week. You also have a two-day Federal Reserve meeting which ends on Wednesday. We're not going to see rates move higher but we're going to be focused on the language out of the Fed, and what they say or suggest about the next meeting.

Recon Capital Chief Investment Officer, Kevin Kelley with us standing by in our New York studios. Technology earnings should set the tone, what do you expect on earnings? Is the Fed a factor? What drives market this week, Kevin?

KEVIN KELLEY, RECON CAPITAL CIO: It's going to be a very, very wild week especially for the Nasdaq 100. You're going to have about 40 percent of the companies reporting this week alone. So that's going to dictate a lot of the market action.

And as you alluded to earlier, the big tech names are really going to drive that but also biotech will be reporting this week as well. And you're seeing a lot of these names, are big growers in their space, except for Apple. Apple is expected to have 22 to 25 percent revenue decline and that's because of the refreshed cycle on the iPhone.

So, we're going to have to see where software and services going that route but you're seeing all the other names including Facebook, Amazon. You're seeing their growth be pretty significant, above 20 percent on the top line revenue growth and 15 percent on the earnings growth.

So people are really going to be focused on that, because companies are going to give their guidance, but it's expected to do very well. And these are companies that are giving a good value. So when you look at the tech sector alone, it's training in a 20 perfect discount to its forward earnings on a historical basis. So, people maybe getting into this and really actually help make this sector move higher and move the overall market higher this week.

BARTIROMO: Even Amazon? That's the company that's -- not going to cover up the flow (ph), right Dagen? That stock is up.

MCDOWELL: Price is up -- maybe price for perfection and the question is, in terms of the forward-looking earnings are those estimates wrong? Do they need to come down because that made -- that could make the stocks not look like .

BARTIROMO: I'm not beating (ph) against Amazon.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, Apple is down 6 percent this year. It really fell off a cliff. It's come back a little bit but in terms of potential upside there, I've heard people talking about that.

KELLEY: Yeah .

BARTIROMO: With Amazon -- yeah.

KELLEY: It's really limited upside on Apple but -- just so you know on the Amazon front, Amazon is a great company that hasn't really focused on earnings. They've really focused on revenue growth. So when people start talking about a fundamental basis and their earnings, you can't focus on that, because what they could do is they could actually slash all of their expenditures and really make it into a great value stock if they wanted to but they're not focused on that. That's why you're seeing in perform quarter over quarter on a basis. That's why you're seeing lead even in the Cloud space.

So, their Amazon is going to be a company that ends up being a Cloud company that happens to have an eCommerce platform.

BARTIROMO: Yeah. You know what? Investors have not been bothered by that that they focus on revenue growth. They keep buying the stock.

MCDOWELL: They can hold their nose only so long and then they have to breath through their nose and look out block (ph).

BARTIROMO: We'll see. Kevin, any other highlights from your standpoint? Do you care about the Fed, Tuesday, Wednesday?

KELLEY: I don't think the Fed is really muted right now especially because people are not expecting a move, and if they are expecting a move they're looking it to be in December or early next year. So people -- investors aren't really focused on that, and they're not even focused on the bank of Japan either because of the move last month.

So, people were going to be focused on the market. Yup, exactly. All about earnings.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, I think (ph) the Japan, is on Friday. All right, Kevin, thank you.

We are awaiting big news this morning form month all about earnings from Verizon reports out that say it is going to be completing inking a $5 billion deal to acquire Yahoo. What it means for CEO Marissa Mayer and shareholders of Yahoo and Verizon. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Live from the 2016 Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. You are watching a special edition of Mornings with Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good Monday morning everybody, welcome back. I am Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, July 25th.

END

urn:contentItem:5KB2-S631-JBHT-D107-00000-00Democratic Convention Opens Today; DNC Chair Resigns Following Email Disclosure; At Least Two Killed in Another Nightclub Shooting in Florida;2016-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:30ZLexisNexisDemocratic Convention Opens Today; DNC Chair Resigns Following Email Disclosure; At Least Two Killed in Another Nightclub Shooting in Florida;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Monday morning, everybody. It is Monday, July 25th. We are coming to you live from the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.

Your top stories right now at 6 a.m. on the East Coast.

Drama at the Democratic National Convention. And it hasn't even started yet. Party Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigning after an e-mail that shows the DNC favored Clinton over rival Bernie Sanders in the primary. Clinton says she was unaware, but Sanders pushed back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I can't speak to let people who were not working for me, who were saying whatever they were saying, I can't speak to that. I can only speak to my campaign.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I), VERMONT: I think it's outrageous, but it is not a great shock to me. I think as I said, it's what we talked about six months ago. I mean, there's no question in my mind and I think no question to any objective observer's mind that the DNC was supporting Hillary Clinton.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This raising new questions this morning about party unity. Sanders had to address the convention tonight and his supporters already filling the streets, protesting all day yesterday and today expected.

Breaking news meanwhile. Another nightclub shooting in Florida. At least two people have been killed, 17 others injured. Authorities searching for the suspect. We have the latest details ahead.

A dangerous heat wave whipping half of the country. A look at when temperatures will begin to drop, coming up. And in Southern California, a massive wildfire growing rapidly. More than 1,000 residents evacuated as firefighters battle that blaze.

Yahoo reportedly finally with a buyer. Verizon is the buyer expected to announce it is acquiring the struggling technology company today for nearly $5 billion. Yahoo will not be the only tech company making headlines this week. Giants including Apple, Facebook, Google parent company Alphabet all set to report their quarterly results.

We will have a preview. New signs that the housing market is coming back. A new survey says homes are flying off the market, so fire is better act fast. We'll bring all the latest news there.

And markets this morning edging higher. take a look at futures really flat on the session indicating a fractional move to the upside for the Doe Jones Industrial average.

Later this week, investors have a lot to digest between economic data and earnings news which continues to flow out this week.

In Europe, stocks are higher across the board. Take a look at the performances. We see the FJ, CAC 40, and DAX index, the German DAX index up almost 1 percent.

All of those stories coming up this morning. And here with me to break it all down, Fox Business Networks' Dagen McDowell, Maverick PAC national co- chair, Morgan Ortagus, and republican strategist, Tony Sayegh.

Good to see you, everybody.

TONY SAYEGH, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Good morning, Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Shall we kick it off, we get here and the first thing is distraction. Debbie Wasserman Schultz is out.

MCDOWELL: I said that how do democrats say unity? That's how you say unity for democrats.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. But we've got that coming up.

To join us this morning we've got a great line up. Former adviser to President Bill Clinton and author of "Armageddon, How Trump Can Beat Hillary," Dick Morris is with us this morning.

Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee will join us. Congressman Caroline Maloney will be here. CLINTON: I think that it is fair to say there has been a concerted effort to convince people like that young man of something. Nobody is quite sure what but of something. I often feel like there's the Hillary standard and then there's the standard for everybody else.

SCOTT PELLEY, "60 MINUTES" HOST: What's the Hillary standard?

CLINTON: Well, it is, you know, a lot of as you saw at the Republican Convention, unfounded, inaccurate, main spirited attacks with no basis in truth reality which take on a life of their own.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MORRIS: Well .

BARTIROMO: So, what do you think? Is there a Hillary standard?

MORRIS: I'm glad his speech writer didn't call it a vast right-wing conspiracy. May be they used that one already. But I think that -- yeah, when somebody comes out of a bar at night, they had a nice drink. When the guy has five DUI (ph), there's a question to whether they shouldn't have been in that bar in the first place, and that is the Hillary standard.

But I think that it is -- when we look at this convention, Donald Trump used this convention to show who Donald Trump is. He was front and center of his family, his wife, his kids. Hillary is going to use this convention to hide herself. She is not running. The first woman is running. She's not running, pro-choice is running and pro-gun control. She's the only person between Donald Trump and the presidency.

And in .

BARTIROMO: That is great analysis, yeah.

MORRIS: . in fact she advances through generic rather than through the specific of her.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, that's a great point. You know, and maybe (ph) she might also have created that standard for herself by just doing things like, oh, I am going to -- you have my own e-mail server, because that's what I'm going to do and nobody else can do that.

TONY SAYEGH, JAMESTOWN ASSOCIATES: The most of these in part of that interview was she said that all these concerns about her honesty untrustworthiness were baseless. Meanwhile, we know from the Clinton Foundation contribution for foreign government, the server and et cetera, but Delegates County saying, you've known Hillary Clinton for decades. You advise the Clintons a long time ago. Has Hillary changed or is this the same Hillary you sat down with face to face when you first met the Clinton's back. I believe it was in the 80's.

BARTIMORO: Real quick, Dick.

MORRIS: I think best say to say it, she's metastasized. In the beginning, there was the incipient dishonesty, there was the incipient paranoia and secrecy.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MORRIS: There was the incipient dishonesty corruption but it's grown. It's metastasized. It's taken her over. You know a person from 70 years old, you knew when they were 30, and you could see them going off the track but not that much.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

MORRIS: But then a 60s and 70s you say, oh, my god, look at what they've become, that's Hillary.

BARTIROMO: Well, you know them really well. And Dick, good to see you, sir. Thank you so much.

MORRIS: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, quite morning in terms of futures. Take a look, we're really not far from where the market finished the day yesterday, and yet earnings really driving the story. Handful of names on the new this morning.

SolarCity is (inaudible) higher. The company reportedly closed to emerge their deal with Tesla. Reuters is reporting that the two companies are in final stages of talks in carrying out due diligence on a potential deal. Stock as you can see looking higher.

Well, the initial report of the deal came out last month. Questions were raised because Elon Musk is the CEO of Tesla and the Chairman of SolarCity. Musk has refused himself from voting on this deal.

We'll continue to track the latest development following a fatal explosion in Germany yesterday. Cheryl Casone with that right now and the other head lines from our New York headquarters. Cheryl, over to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS: Yeah, that's right Maria. The various interior minister says he believes the incident was likely an Islamist suicide attack. Police say a 27-year old Syrian man blew himself up after he was turned away from an open air music festival in Ansbach.

Police believe the man who killed himself was motivated after being denied asylum in Germany. He was already known to them for a recent drug misdemeanor. At least 12 others were injured in the suicide attack.

We'll here at home. A wildfire in Southern California, destroying 18 homes and rapidly gaining straight two days after it broke out. The fire being described as a freight train by some setting so much smoke into the air that planes making water drops on it, had to be grounded (ph) at one point. Thousands of people forced to evacuate.

This fire Maria has burned at least 34 square miles but fire officials say that size may now have doubled. Of course, it's dark in California. We'll see what happens when the sun comes up this morning.

And finally, the housing market, showing signs of improvement. (Inaudible) said that homes are selling an average of a week faster than they did just one year ago. This is the supply of nearly 5 percent lower than last year. Homes are being sold after about 78 days on the market. The average U.S. home is currently worth $187,000, Maria, that's a 5.4 percent increase from June of last year. That's for prices from 2015.

But Maria, remember, that we're also looking about 3.5 percent for the 30- year fixed year mortgage right now, that's also affecting sales. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you so much, Cheryl. Spotlight on technology this week, setting the stage on market. Coming up, we're going to preview the week. We'll tell you what to expect, out of a whole host (ph) of earnings within the tech sector.

Plus, we're coming to you live from Democratic National Convention here in Philadelphia. We'll tell about what to expect as the DNC kicks off today. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Let's check market this morning with a lot of earnings coming out this weekend some economic data that will certainly set the tone and the Fed. Two-day meeting, the Federal Reserve is having this week.

Ahead of all of that, the market is looking fractionally higher. It keeps going back and forth though between positive and negative territory, this following another record closing high for the S&P 500 on Friday.

Investors are gearing up for a slow of Vect (ph) technology earning including S&P components, Apple which is also a Dow component, reporting earnings tomorrow. Facebook is out on Wednesday. Amazon is out and Google parent Alphabet are out with their results on Thursday.

This is going to be a big week. You also have a two-day Federal Reserve meeting which ends on Wednesday. We're not going to see rates move higher but we're going to be focused on the language out of the Fed, and what they say or suggest about the next meeting.

Recon Capital Chief Investment Officer, Kevin Kelley with us standing by in our New York studios. Technology earnings should set the tone, what do you expect on earnings? Is the Fed a factor? What drives market this week, Kevin?

KEVIN KELLEY, RECON CAPITAL CIO: It's going to be a very, very wild week especially for the Nasdaq 100. You're going to have about 40 percent of the companies reporting this week alone. So that's going to dictate a lot of the market action.

And as you alluded to earlier, the big tech names are really going to drive that but also biotech will be reporting this week as well. And you're seeing a lot of these names, are big growers in their space, except for Apple. Apple is expected to have 22 to 25 percent revenue decline and that's because of the refreshed cycle on the iPhone.

So, we're going to have to see where software and services going that route but you're seeing all the other names including Facebook, Amazon. You're seeing their growth be pretty significant, above 20 percent on the top line revenue growth and 15 percent on the earnings growth.

So people are really going to be focused on that, because companies are going to give their guidance, but it's expected to do very well. And these are companies that are giving a good value. So when you look at the tech sector alone, it's training in a 20 perfect discount to its forward earnings on a historical basis. So, people maybe getting into this and really actually help make this sector move higher and move the overall market higher this week.

BARTIROMO: Even Amazon? That's the company that's -- not going to cover up the flow (ph), right Dagen? That stock is up.

MCDOWELL: Price is up -- maybe price for perfection and the question is, in terms of the forward-looking earnings are those estimates wrong? Do they need to come down because that made -- that could make the stocks not look like .

BARTIROMO: I'm not beating (ph) against Amazon.

MCDOWELL: And by the way, Apple is down 6 percent this year. It really fell off a cliff. It's come back a little bit but in terms of potential upside there, I've heard people talking about that.

KELLEY: Yeah .

BARTIROMO: With Amazon -- yeah.

KELLEY: It's really limited upside on Apple but -- just so you know on the Amazon front, Amazon is a great company that hasn't really focused on earnings. They've really focused on revenue growth. So when people start talking about a fundamental basis and their earnings, you can't focus on that, because what they could do is they could actually slash all of their expenditures and really make it into a great value stock if they wanted to but they're not focused on that. That's why you're seeing in perform quarter over quarter on a basis. That's why you're seeing lead even in the Cloud space.

So, their Amazon is going to be a company that ends up being a Cloud company that happens to have an eCommerce platform.

BARTIROMO: Yeah. You know what? Investors have not been bothered by that that they focus on revenue growth. They keep buying the stock.

MCDOWELL: They can hold their nose only so long and then they have to breath through their nose and look out block (ph).

BARTIROMO: We'll see. Kevin, any other highlights from your standpoint? Do you care about the Fed, Tuesday, Wednesday?

KELLEY: I don't think the Fed is really muted right now especially because people are not expecting a move, and if they are expecting a move they're looking it to be in December or early next year. So people -- investors aren't really focused on that, and they're not even focused on the bank of Japan either because of the move last month.

So, people were going to be focused on the market. Yup, exactly. All about earnings.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, I think (ph) the Japan, is on Friday. All right, Kevin, thank you.

We are awaiting big news this morning form month all about earnings from Verizon reports out that say it is going to be completing inking a $5 billion deal to acquire Yahoo. What it means for CEO Marissa Mayer and shareholders of Yahoo and Verizon. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Live from the 2016 Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. You are watching a special edition of Mornings with Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good Monday morning everybody, welcome back. I am Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, July 25th.

urn:contentItem:5KB2-S631-JBHT-D10C-00000-00Democratic Convention Opens Today; DNC Chair Resigns Following Email Disclosure; At Least Two Killed in Another Nightclub Shooting in Florida;2016-07-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:39:30ZLexisNexisDemocratic Convention Opens Today; DNC Chair Resigns Following Email Disclosure; At Least Two Killed in Another Nightclub Shooting in Florida;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Good Monday morning, everybody. It is Monday, July 25th. We are coming to you live from the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.

Your top stories right now at 6 a.m. on the East Coast.

Drama at the Democratic National Convention. And it hasn't even started yet. Party Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz resigning after an e-mail that shows the DNC favored Clinton over rival Bernie Sanders in the primary. Clinton says she was unaware, but Sanders pushed back.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HILLARY CLINTON, (D) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I can't speak to let people who were not working for me, who were saying whatever they were saying, I can't speak to that. I can only speak to my campaign.

SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I), VERMONT: I think it's outrageous, but it is not a great shock to me. I think as I said, it's what we talked about six months ago. I mean, there's no question in my mind and I think no question to any objective observer's mind that the DNC was supporting Hillary Clinton.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This raising new questions this morning about party unity. Sanders had to address the convention tonight and his supporters already filling the streets, protesting all day yesterday and today expected.

Breaking news meanwhile. Another nightclub shooting in Florida. At least two people have been killed, 17 others injured. Authorities searching for the suspect. We have the latest details ahead.

A dangerous heat wave whipping half of the country. A look at when temperatures will begin to drop, coming up. And in Southern California, a massive wildfire growing rapidly. More than 1,000 residents evacuated as firefighters battle that blaze.

Yahoo reportedly finally with a buyer. Verizon is the buyer expected to announce it is acquiring the struggling technology company today for nearly $5 billion. Yahoo will not be the only tech company making headlines this week. Giants including Apple, Facebook, Google parent company Alphabet all set to report their quarterly results.

We will have a preview. New signs that the housing market is coming back. A new survey says homes are flying off the market, so fire is better act fast. We'll bring all the latest news there.

And markets this morning edging higher. take a look at futures really flat on the session indicating a fractional move to the upside for the Doe Jones Industrial average.

Later this week, investors have a lot to digest between economic data and earnings news which continues to flow out this week.

In Europe, stocks are higher across the board. Take a look at the performances. We see the FJ, CAC 40, and DAX index, the German DAX index up almost 1 percent.

All of those stories coming up this morning. And here with me to break it all down, Fox Business Networks' Dagen McDowell, Maverick PAC national co- chair, Morgan Ortagus, and republican strategist, Tony Sayegh.

Good to see you, everybody.

TONY SAYEGH, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Good morning, Maria.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Shall we kick it off, we get here and the first thing is distraction. Debbie Wasserman Schultz is out.

MCDOWELL: I said that how do democrats say unity? That's how you say unity for democrats.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. But we've got that coming up.

To join us this morning we've got a great line up. Former adviser to President Bill Clinton and author of "Armageddon, How Trump Can Beat Hillary," Dick Morris is with us this morning.

Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee will join us. Congressman Caroline Maloney will be here. Former astronaut, husband of former Representative Gabriel Gifford, and co-founder of American for Responsible Solutions, Mark Kelly is joining us this morning. And former Michigan Governor and senior of Correct the Record, a super PAC67 backing Hillary Clinton, Jennifer Granholm will be with us as well.

Disorder at the DNC this morning. A major shakeup rocking the Democratic Party emitted in the e-mail scandal just hours before the Democratic national Convention kicks in Philadelphia.

Let's get right to Blake Burman, he's here in Philly with the very latest. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, there, Maria. God morning to you as well. Debbie Wasserman Schulz will gather in the Democratic National Conventional later today. She'll give a speech at some point this week. Gavel it out on Thursday and that will be it.

For her is that the Democratic National Committee as Wasserman Schultz yesterday resigned from the top post at the DNC. Of course, this is due to the fallout of the WikiLeaks scandal. WikiLeaks over the weekend releasing some 19,000 plus e-mails that showed during the primary process.

Top democratic officials, some of them favored Hillary Clinton over Bernie Sanders even in some states trying to tip the scales towards Clinton. Wasserman Schultz herself even had some choice words when describing Sanders campaign manager.

Now, Hillary Clinton was asked about those e-mails over the weekend, in an interview with 60 Minutes. I should note that she gave this interview before Wasserman Schultz officially submitted her letter of resignation. Hear now Hillary Clinton about the e-mails.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: I didn't know anything about it and I haven't read any of those. But I am adamantly opposed to anyone bringing religion into our political process.

Again, I don't know anything. I don't know anything about -- about these e- mails. I haven't followed it. But I'm very proud of the campaign that I ran.

I can't speak to what people who were not working for me, who were saying whatever they were singing. I can't speak to that. I can only speak to my campaign.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Donald Trump as you might was not staying silent during all of this. He had several responses via Twitter. Among them I'll read you one here, quote "Because the democrats are in a total meltdown, but the biased media will say how great they are doing. E-mail say the rigged system is alive and well."

Of course, Maria, Trump has been saying that the system was rigged against Bernie Sanders. He will try to use this to try to sway some Sanders to his side, and in something that you can't make up, Maria. The theme here tonight for the democrats, "United together." Ted Cruz and all of that was so last week. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it's true. I mean, so much conversation about last week, and yet here we are kicking this often and this happens. Blake, thank you. Blake Burman with the latest there.

I want to bring in former Congressman Dennis Kucinich, a former presidential candidate himself and Fox News contributor. Congressman, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DENNIS KUCINICH, FORMER OHIO STATE REPRESENTATIVE: Great to be with you.

BARTIROMO: First, your reaction to the e-mail scandal, WikiLeaks releasing 20,000 e-mails and that's obviously it came to life.

KUCINICH: What reflects the culture inside the Democratic National Committee. And as such, I think that when you add up all of the things, setting the debate schedule that was insufficient, that super delegates. There's so many things which basically prove that this election was rigged against Bernie Sanders.

BARTIROMO: You think, now -- we were talking on the commercial break. You think Bernie Sanders should do more.

KUCINICH: Well, I actually think that it's time for him to consider withdrawing the endorsement. Because it's not just about him, it's about the movement that he represents which had 46 percent of the votes for the country.

BARTIROMO: yes.

KUCINICH: And it was that kind of conduct was totally dismissive of almost half of the democratic voters. And you cannot have that kind of contempt for voters. And I think Bernie, I would -- I think he ought to at least consider withdrawing the endorsement.

BARTIROMO: You know, we've been talking and hearing from the Democratic National Committee yesterday as this is happening, Tony Sayegh. They kept saying, well, he wasn't going to win anyway. But the truth is we'll never know that for sure.

SAYEGH: Well, doesn't that confirm the whole idea that it was rigged in the first place.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: You have to make that -- to make that...

SAYEGH: And the evolution is crazy, Maria. You and I were together yesterday morning. At that point, Debbie Wasserman Schultz has just said she's not going to speak at the convention.

By the end of the day, and Bernie Sanders interview had I think a lot to do it. She was out as the head of the DNC. But, Congressman, I agree with you. I think Bernie Sanders should be strong and may be reconsidering his endorsement. It doesn't sound like he's going to do that though. But it sounds like his followers are pretty darn mad.

KUCINICH: Well, they are. And, you know, as a former candidate for president, I can tell you that, you know, you cannot expect the people who support you to just go lockstep when then you say. And so that, you know, there's the Bernie movement is a little bit separate from what the candidate might want to do.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KUCINICH: And I want to go back to what you just said, Maria, where the DNC's excuse was he wasn't going to win anyways. In other words, their conduct, actually help to create a self-fulfilling prophecy where Bernie was locked up because the game was rigged.

BARTIROMO: That's right. And remember when we were watching all of those democrats, we were all scratching our heads saying, why are they doing it when the playoffs are on.

KUCINICH: Hello.

BARTIROMO: Why are they doing it on a Saturday night when no one watches - - or Sunday night. I mean, they were all very low, you know, viewing night when they did these debates.

MORGAN ORTAGUS, MAVERICK PAC NATIONAL CO-CHAIR: But, Congressman, don't you think this is immedicable larger cultural problem within the DNC within, you know, when Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Hillary Clinton, this the second e-mail scandal in the past year with the Democratic Party.

But don't you think that the party itself needs to look and say, you know, we have a cultural leadership problem here where we're allowing this cronyism to go on and fair tactics to go on that if the Republican Party did, we'd be skewered for doing this.

KUCINICH: Well, that is true. But let's go one step further. This is a whole new era where technology is impacting politics in a powerful way.

ORTAGUS: Right.

KUCINICH: This is the millennial will understand this better than anyone. Because you don't put anything in an e-mail that you wouldn't expect to have to read publicly. And so, the politicians are just getting caught up.

And I think caught up and I think that what it reflects is an older political culture that a pre-internet and it hasn't really caught up.

And so, again, but there has to be some kind of and say this is not right. This kind of politics cannot be -- cannot be -- cannot continue.

SAYEGH: Congressman, I suspect that this has disturbed you as much as it disturb me and others. The idea that it was revealed they were contemplating using Bernie Sanders religious beliefs...

ORTAGUS: Yes.

SAYEGH: ... as a campaign issue. And at the time where particularly as republicans were often demonized by our opponents for being racist, being bigoted in some fashion. Certainly our presidential candidate today is assail by those things.

Doesn't that reveal hypocrisy that they were actually willing to do it against their own?

(CROSSTALK)

KUCINICH: Well, I think it goes a little bit worse than hypocrisy. Here's why. The head of the DNC, Jewish, OK. And probably so. An that's a good thing. But how can you have under lengths trying to trap somebody, you know, about his religion which also happens to be Jewish.

BARTIROMO: Right.

KUCINICH: I mean, it boggles the mind. And so, this is...

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: The cultural problem.

BARTIROMO: One of -- the e-mails was -- one of the officials basically saying somebody needs to ask him, do you even believe in God. And then he said, look, my peeps in West Virginia are going to -- that will really resonate with them, you know. Maybe he is an Atheist. Now he's Jewish.

KUCINICH: Well, you know, the question now is that the DNC believe in fairness? Does the DNC believe in the Constitution of the United States and Freedom of Religion?

BARTIROMO: Right.

KUCINICH: Does the DNC believe in trying to unite the party?

ORTAGUS: I wouldn't be surprise to see two campaigns to have sort of e- mails going back and forth. But I think the crucial difference here is not that these are two campaigns. This is the Democratic National Committee overtly planning how to take one of their candidates.

KUCINICH: There's no way to defend us. It's indefensible.

BARTIROMO: So, tonight, Bernie Sanders will speak. Tonight, we'll see what he says. We'll see if he addresses this. That's' going to be something to watch.

KUCINICH: he's going to need to address.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And Michelle Obama, the First Lady will speak tonight. So, we will be obviously covering that. Congressman, good to see you.

KUCINICH: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Congressman Kucinich there. We will be live from the Democratic National Convention tonight in Philadelphia all week. Don't miss our special primetime coverage, I'll here that off tonight at 6 p.m. Eastern, followed by Lou Dobbs and Trish Regan. So, do join us for our special coverage tonight.

Meanwhile, we are following the breaking news out of a nightclub shooting in Fort Myers, Florida. At last two people are dead, 17 injured. We will bring you the very latest from this deadly shooting in Florida.

Yahoo, meanwhile may have finally found a new home in Verizon. Reports say Verizon is set to announce the nearly $5 billion deal this morning. Interesting to know that back in the day Microsoft was willing to pay $48 billion. Verizon will pay 5 billion. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. A fatal shooting at a Florida nightclub early this morning to report. Cheryl Casone with the story and the other headlines right now in our New York headquarters. Cheryl, good morning to you.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, good morning, Maria. Well, officials say that at least two people were killed and as many as 17 others injured in a shooting outside of a Florida nightclub. This happened just after midnight in Fort Myers at Club Blu.

Gunshots ring out in the parking lot and at this hour there are two active crime scenes that we know off. Authorities say that injuries range from minor to life-threatening at this hour.

Three people have been taken into custody and the investigation is continuing right now. We'll bring updates if we get them, Maris.

Also this today, a deadly heat wave continuing to blanket parts of the United States. Six people including a 12-year-old boy in Arizona who died from the heat as near triple digit temperatures sports state from New York all the way to California.

Cody's mom was hiking in the snowy mountains when he suffered a fatal heat strike. This happened in Phoenix, Arizona. Across the country, Maria, temperatures got in 100 today, in particular in New York, Philadelphia, and Washington. The heat index could be much higher if you combine the temperature and humidity.

And finally, in business headlines this morning, the long process is over. It appears that Verizon has come out on top in the biddings for Yahoo.
